subject: Home & DIY
title: Rainwater Harvesting Is Ancient and Modern
description: A fast breakdown of Rainwater Harvesting Is Ancient and Modern for builders.

hook.text: A 1,000 sq ft roof collects 600 gallons from just one inch of rain. That's enough to flush toilets for two weeks.

buildup.text: From the Nabataeans to the Aztecs, civilizations harvested rain. It was the primary water source for millennia.

discovery.text: Modern systems filter runoff through mesh screens and first-flush diverters, then store it in tanks for gardens.

twist.text: Some US states banned rainwater collection for decades, claiming rain 'belonged' to downstream rights holders.

climax.text: Most states now encourage it. Colorado, once strictest, legalized residential rain barrels in 2016 after a key study.

punchline.text: Free water falls from the sky. Catch it.

quiz.question: Why did some US states historically restrict rainwater harvesting?
options: Rain was legally considered property of downstream water rights holders
Health officials feared contamination from roof runoff
Municipal water companies lobbied against competing supplies
